Articles.Content: How is it that with various chemical engines like the SSME that there thrust is recorded at say 104-108% thrust? How can the max thrust be measured higher than 100%?
Because they improved the engine during the space shuttles lifetime.
Improvements were made to the engines later on. They could then provide more thrust than they originally could. Hence the extra % of thrust.

It's also not uncommon for the rating of an engine to really mean "maximum sustained output without risk of failure", which rating the engine can exceed for brief periods, though that is apparently not the case here.
My understanding is that "100%" is a standard established full thrust. If they set it to full throttle, it probably goes a bit past that.
The reason it goes to 108% and they didn't just make that the new 100% is due to the launch profiles and other technicalities they didn't want to bother with.
